awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Transcranial Dynamic Focused Ultrasound for the Non-Invasive Opening of the Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB)
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to enable new therapeutic strategies to treat brain diseases such a brain cancer. Treating brain diseases is challenging partly because of the existence of an anatomical structure called the blood-brain barrier. This barrier prevents the entry of almost all therapeutic molecules into the brain tissue from the blood. This has led to a devastating impact on the patients and society as a whole. As an example, for glioblastoma, the most common form of primary malignant brain tumors, the five-year survival rate is only 6.8%. Impact and commercial potential include increased treatment options where few or none are available and improved patient outcomes, all with a system that is patient-friendly and designed to cause minimal disruption to the existing treatment workflows. Additionally, the advancement of this project will provide a convenient tool for drug developers to study and develop new drugs without the need to develop a special carrier to transport drugs into the brain. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project involves designing and building a prototype version of a system that can deliver therapies to the brain in a non-invasive and non-intrusive manner. The performance of this system to accurately deliver to regions of interest within the brain will be measured and characterized in a test environment mimicking that of a human head. This project will advance a prototype for use in both clinical and research settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Brain diseases are difficult to diagnose and treat. The brain is a special organ and is protected by its anatomy even from the rest of the body. Part of this protection is provided by the blood-brain barrier. The walls of blood vessels within the brain, form a tight mesh preventing all but essential substances such as nutrients and waste from passing between the blood and the surrounding brain tissue. These walls of the blood vessels collectively form the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Due to the makeup of the BBB, most drugs administered orally or intravenously cannot pass from the blood to the diseased portions of the brain. Focused ultrasound can open this barrier temporarily and safely with the help of microbubbles (an intravenously injected contrast agent used regularly in diagnostic ultrasound imaging). Opening the BBB enables two important applications that can be of great benefit to patients with brain diseases: (1) drugs can be made to cross the BBB and reach diseased parts of the brain and, (2) disease biomarkers can pass from diseased tissue into the blood. These disease biomarkers can subsequently be detected in blood drawn from example from the arm. As disease biomarkers carry information about the disease, the technique of temporarily and safely opening the blood-brain barrier with focused ultrasound enables liquid biopsy or a way to diagnose diseases of the brain without doing invasive surgery.

 

In this Phase II project, we designed, built, and performed benchtop testing of a prototype device that can open the BBB non-invasively. We built a test object that mimics the human head in its physical (i.e. size) and acoustic properties. This test object also included several features such as vessels (mimicking vessels in the brain) and insertion channels or ports that allowed us to insert measurement instruments inside the test object and measure the in-situ acoustic pressure. Using this test object, our device, and our technique, we can simulate how our device may be used in a real situation with an actual patient. Using the MRI and CT images of this test object (as we would in a real situation), we verified the ability of our technique to guide ultrasound to a desired location (within the test object) non-invasively. We were able to demonstrate that our non-invasive guidance worked as expected; the ultrasound beams generated by our device reached the desired location as per our criteria. We also built a software (i.e. simulation) tool to calculate sound propagation in complex media such as the skull and brain. This tool is “patient-specific” in that we incorporate the acoustic and physical properties of the patient. We use this tool to estimate and control the acoustic energy that is generated and transmitted into the head when our device is in use and applied to patients. Again, using our test object, we verified the performance of this tool by comparing the simulated results to actual measurements. The simulations and the measurements matched as per the predefined success criteria. The significance of this result is that with additional testing and verification, we can use this tool to estimate the in-situ acoustic pressure in a real human head due to ultrasound beams generated by our device when applied to a patient. The acoustic pressure is an important parameter to control to achieve a safe opening of the BBB; thus, a reliable pressure estimator is an important tool to have.

 

The learning and results of our Phase II project can be broadly applied to brain diseases from brain tumors to Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease. Thus, with additional development, testing, and verification, our device can have a significant impact on patients with brain diseases by enabling new methods to manage these diseases from diagnostics to therapeutics. Additionally, beyond opening the BBB non-invasively, our device and the tools can also be used in other applications such as neuromodulation. Finally, while we are working in neurology, it may be possible to generalize our device and tools to other anatomy, extending the impact of this project.

 


Last Modified: 01/18/2024
Modified by: Bhaskar S Ramamurthy
